winning_value: RAM-only execution with no writes to internal disk by default
losing_value: RAM overwrite on shutdown to mitigate cold-boot attacks

winning_value: RAM-only execution with no writes to internal disk by default
losing_value: Optional persistent storage that is encrypted but forensically detectable as an encrypted volume

winning_value: All Tor-based privacy OS stacks share Tor susceptibility to traffic correlation and website fingerprinting
losing_value: Live RAM capture of running Tails session can recover substantial user artefacts despite amnesic design

winning_value: All Tor-based privacy OS stacks share Tor susceptibility to traffic correlation and website fingerprinting
losing_value: Weaker isolation story for long-running compartmented workflows due to single-OS instance

winning_value: All Tor-based privacy OS stacks share Tor susceptibility to traffic correlation and website fingerprinting
losing_value: Running Tails in a VM undermines amnesic guarantees because host can inspect RAM and I/O

winning_value: All Tor-based privacy OS stacks share Tor susceptibility to traffic correlation and website fingerprinting
losing_value: SANS DFIR forensic analysis shows memory imaging of live Tails sessions yields extensive recoverable artefacts

winning_value: Normal persistent VMs on disk; no amnesic guarantee; requires full-disk encryption on host
losing_value: Isolation quality depends on host OS and hypervisor security; host compromise defeats VM separation

winning_value: Browser RCE blast radius by confining compromise to disposable AppVM
losing_value: State-level attacker with moderate isolation rating; Tails provides moderate-weak; containers provide weak-moderate

winning_value: Container isolation shares kernel with host making kernel exploits a full-escape vector
losing_value: Containerised browser isolation is incremental hardening of mainstream OSes not a full anonymity architecture

winning_value: VPN provider can see user real IP and that it connects to Tor guards
losing_value: Adding VPN before Tor does not prevent global adversary from correlating flows across both sides of Tor

winning_value: VPN provider can see user real IP and that it connects to Tor guards
losing_value: VPN protocols such as OpenVPN can be reliably fingerprinted and blocked by censors using DPI

winning_value: VPN provider can see user real IP and that it connects to Tor guards
losing_value: Empirical studies show commercial VPN providers are heterogeneous and some leak traffic or misrepresent logging policies

winning_value: VPN provider can see user real IP and that it connects to Tor guards
losing_value: Data retention laws can require VPN providers in some jurisdictions to store connection logs for years

winning_value: VPN provider can see user real IP and that it connects to Tor guards
losing_value: Tor Project documentation generally does not recommend using a VPN with Tor for typical users

winning_value: WF attacker accuracy by approximately 61.5 percent relative to undefended Tor as best padding-only result
losing_value: Flow correlation TPR at 10e-5 FPR to approximately 0.12 which is less than half of next-best defense
